Blockchain: the unbreakable net of Trust; the non evil Matrix or Skynet…

I always wondered why sci-fi movies that picture a dark future, sell more than the ones that project tomorrows with bright outcomes… For me, movies such as The Bicentennial Man (1999) or Startrek IV: The Voyage Home (1986), who explore better futures and nice consequences of technology, added to very emotional stories, are brilliant works of art, psychology and philosophy, that got unfair relatively low grades on imdb. By the way, both were filmed in the magical and beautiful San Francisco, "the 49 square miles surrounded by reality"…

In both these wonderful movies, the subject money was approached: in Bicentennial Man, the owner of the intelligent robot Andrew (that by "malfunction" developed emotions), tries to open a bank account for "it"; eventually he manages to open one for Andrew, that had no SSN neither human ID, but only after much effort from his lawyer friends.

In Startrek IV: The Voyage Home, Kirk and crew come back from the 23rd century future to the past San Francisco of 1986, and, upon arriving, Kirk warns his people to beware, since they are now within a primitive society that "still uses money" and that got to use "colorful metaphors in order to be able to get attention in a conversation" (i.e, swearing)

On the other hand, movies such as The Matrix (1999) or Terminator (1984), that orbit the concept of a gloom future where humans are destroyed or dominated by machines, get much higher grades on imdb as well as more fame. OK, both of these 2 movies are well done, creative but… they do not go that "deep inside us" as the previous 2 other movies I mentioned do.

The Matrix and Terminator have in common the same major evil: the networked computers of the world, that, upon achieving advanced AI (Artificial Intelligence) capabilities, rebells and wants to dominate and/or destroy all human beings. They explore apparently a collective unconscious fear that, it seems, a good part of humanity shares: of being swallowed or controlled by a "world wide web" of computers that, upon gaining consciousness, wants to destroy us.

Isaac Asimov was the brilliant author of the short story of the same name that inspired The Bicentennial Man, one of his best robot stories. Asimov was Russian, and moved with his family to the USA when he was a child in 1923, between the 1st and 2nd world wars. He wrote more than 500 books and 90,000 letters. To my knowledge, only Mozart was as prolific as Asimov was. Asimov used to say that his books wrote themselves, as Mozart said about his music.

Asimov was also the father of AI, upon creating the 3 laws of robotics in his first masterpiece book about robots, called I Robot. Unfortunately, a movie was made with this same name, that completely distorted Asimov’s stories and beliefs. It also had Asimov's characters, that featured as a key one Susan Calvin, a robot psychologist, but with characteristics totally changed from the much more deep and bold ones of Asimov's books. Once again, Hollywood "biz selling logic" transformed the robots in evil creatures that wanted to dominate the world. Asimov never wrote such things!

Asimov conceived, with logic, art and deep scientific knowledge, robots as perfect beings. Incapable, by root logic embedded in their positronic brains, of harming men or humanity, as stated in the 3 laws of Robotics. Actually, some human beings in Asimov's stories even hated the robots because of such perfection. An immature envy reaction to something that is undeniably better and superior. Susan Calvin, the robot psychologist that was a superbly brilliant character created by Asimov, said, in one of his great robot stories, that robots are so similar to humans in our positive characteristics, that humans inadvertently expect them to act having the same negative aspects of ourselves; but such thing cannot ever happen. And that is why some humans don’t like them, since they cannot tolerate the existence of a “perfect human being”…

If you think about it, all computer systems are, and always have been, built with Asimov's first law of robotics logic actually. But all such computer systems were and are controlled by man, by human beings. Or by companies, or by governments. So data could and can always be manipulated, changed, cheated by humans.

This was until 2008… the year of the last major global financial crisis… We were not expecting that, in this same scary year, as if to "respond" to the chaos and crisis in the world financial system, on halloween 2008, a mysterious man(?) called Satoshi Nakamoto (that nobody knows who he or she is until now), would announce his invention of the very first autonomous computer system, where data cannot be controlled or manipulated by any human being in the world: the Blockchain. As any computer system, as in The Matrix, the Blockchain depends on humans, of course, to exist. But its data cannot be controlled, altered or manipulated by any human, any company, any government. Oh my God! Are we then building a Skynet or Matrix already? And, what's worse and "scary": this very first autonomous network of computers, was created to deal, immutably store and manage humanity's core business pillars: money, contracts and personal crucial / relevant data!!! An independent net that creates digital money, and has the "intention" to control all money in the world someday…

Yes, Blockchain is a brilliant invention, from an unknown creator, that will make an impact on humanity bigger than the internet itself. Because, if not stopped, along with its inseparable companion Bitcoin, it will inevitably evolve to the point of eliminating the exclusive central control that nowadays banks and governments have on money. It will eliminate all human created currencies. It will eliminate the banks themselves. Including the Central Banks that belong to Governments. I personally believe blockchain, as all technologies, cannot be stopped.

Yes, with Blockchain, we, humans, are taking the first step towards surrendering control of our most precious material things: money, properties, assets, contracts, creations, to a net of machines that no human or human entity can manipulate, no matter how powerful such human entity is. And we are doing that because, finally, Asimov's first law of robotics actually came, in it's integrity, to life. Blockchain can be FULLY TRUSTED to store money, money transactions, contracts, assets, as no human institution can. Blockchain cannot harm a human being or, through inaction, allow a human being to come to harm, when related to such powerful concepts (money, etc), that are the root base of our business world, of humanity's business life.

Blockchain created a way to free humanity from human weaknesses and temptations. It won't cheat and cannot be cheated. We can completely TRUST that data put in the Blockchain will not be altered. Since no human can do it. And we know, for sure, that the machines will not alter data on their own to harm men. We know enough about logic and technology that this is the way it works, for sure. Even if most of us still share the unconscious, illogical fear of a worldwide net of independent machines wanting to destroy us.

Maybe in a similar way that our ancestors feared that, since the world was flat, we would fall into an infinite darkness upon reaching the horizon with our wind powered ships. Or in the same way we wanted to burn men that said the Earth moves around the sun, and it is not the immovable center of the Universe.

Maybe the new generations do not have the present common collective fear of autonomous machine systems that the "adults" reflect in their catastrophic sci-fi movies, and will therefore accelerate the surrender of control to the machines. To actually TRUST them, more and more. To immutably store on the Blockchain, that belongs to no one, contracts, money, assets, with much more confidence that we today delegate the custody of such things to governments, banks, lawyers and notaries. Blockchain is threatening to substantially reduce or even completely eliminate the power of all human beings today involved in such 4 activities, that, come to think of it, exist because of the weaknesses and fears of all of us… Is this a scary scenario for our future, or is it actually a long pursued and very desirable, dream of humanity, starting to come true?

Beyond such amazing and deep disruptions regarding money, contracts and assets, Blockchain will be the basis for the creation of other autonomous machine systems, that will free humanity from other boring, non essential tasks, that do not actually add human value, besides the ones that today are performed by governments, banks, lawyers and notaries, that Blockchain is capable of replacing and improving.

I will write about this in a future article; "stay tuned"… Meanwhile, for those interested in having a glimpse of such futures, I suggest the book "The City and The Stars" by Arthur C. Clarke.
